title: Great Zimbabwe
documentsInfo: We are using, in this text, references to Portuguese and the European calendar, as we are still studying the cultures being presented.

maps.text: Approximate location of the Great Zimbabwe national monument, in Zimbabwe.

common.text:
### Who built Great Zimbabwe?

To answer the question for this section, it is necessary to evaluate various factors. Furthermore, as in any area of study, we must always be attentive to new discoveries, because science is not just theory. Knowledge is constantly being updated (<htcite0>).

#### An initial proposal

The first hypothesis put forward about the origin of the people who built Great Zimbabwe was considered “exotic”. According to this proposal, the people were Semitic, with possible connections to the House of David (<htcite1>). This fact leads us to a reflection:

source.text: Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.

common.text:
Reflection 1: On initial concepts

When we don't have data about a region, is it normal to create explanations based on knowledge we already possess?

When creating these hypotheses, do people generally try to make proposals considering local populations or do they focus on external invasions?

Considering that local populations were not responsible for certain works—can't that underestimate them?

#### Recent studies

A more detailed study of artifacts and genetics showed that the Shona people, responsible for building Great Zimbabwe, are one of the many Bantu-speaking peoples who would have migrated to the region between the years <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

In addition to estimates of the Bantu arrival in the region, we also have an estimate of the initial expansion of the Bantu peoples from the region where Cameroon is located today, between <htdate2> and <htdate3> (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

source.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

common.text:
#### And before the Bantu?

The occupation of Great Zimbabwe would have begun in Period I, initially defined between the years <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite0>). However, as the use of data in the earliest research appears not to have been done with the necessary care (<htcite1>), new studies are being developed to better understand the occupation and how the Shona people occupied and dominated the region.

The new chronology proposed by Shadreck Chirikure, Mark Pollard, Munyaradzi Manyanga and Foreman Bandama indicates that the initial occupation would have occurred between the years <htdate2> and <htdate3> (<htcite2>).

We emphasize that this initial occupation, as we have already seen, would be prior to the arrival of the Bantu speakers (<htcite3>; <htcite4>).

source.text: Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.
Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.
Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.

prerequisites: Before proceeding with the text, we suggest studying the texts on the Bantu expansion already published on History Tracers (Bantu People; The Bantu Expansion).

history.text:
### Period I

The initial occupations of this period were carried out by people who practiced agriculture (<htcite0>).

As discussed above, we understand that the first occupations occurred between the years <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite1>).

Due to the limited information we have about these periods, we will consider that, since Period II, studied next, coincides with the arrival of Bantu language speakers, it is possible to assume that the migrant women in this period might have had the mitochondrial DNA **L0a1a** and **L0a2** (<htcite2>).

source.text: Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.
Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.

sources.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

history.text: We can only assume her DNA and that she was a farmer, like the other people of Period I.
We assume that there was a relationship between him and his wife, after all, there are people living in Zimbabwe today with the described mtDNA.
A woman has been added as a daughter in respect to the matrilineal tradition used by the Bantu people (<htcite0>)

Period II was initially defined between <htdate0> y <htdate1> (<htcite0>). This period is notable for the appearance of glass beads in southeastern Africa, which helps confirm contacts, via the Indian Ocean, with Asia (<htcite1>; <htcite2>).

This period is also notable for the arrival of Bantu peoples in the region (<htcite3>; <htcite4>).

source.text: Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.
Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.

sources.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

history.text:
Excavations demonstrate important changes that occurred at the end of this period, such as the use of glass beads, displayed as illustrated in **Figure 2**. Furthermore, the appearance of ceramics evidencing import practices by the Shona people is also observed (<htcite0>).

Among the ceramics found in the region, we would like to draw attention to pieces originating from China, which still generate controversy among specialists (<htcite1>; <htcite2>).

source.text: Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.
Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.

history.text: Figure 2: Glass Beads. © Trustees of the British Museum (The British Museum).

Given the historical period in question, it is possible to assume this was a Bantu language speaker and, consequently, that she would possibly present a haplogroup common among Bantu men, E1b1a* (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

source.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

history.text: In the same manner as in Period I, a woman has been added as a daughter, respecting the matrilineal tradition used by Bantu peoples (<htcite0>).
Period III of the Greater Zimbabwe region occurred between <htdate0> and <htdate1>. During this period, the stone walls (**Figure 3**) were built (<htcite0>).

source.text: Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.

history.text: Figure 3: Great Zimbabwe National Monument. Photograph taken by Erik Eschweiler-Dienerowitz and made available on the UNESCO website (UNESCO). Shared under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 IGO license.

The precise date of the walls' construction is an open question. As mentioned by Shadreck Chirikure, Mark Pollard, Munyaradzi Manyanga, and Foreman Bandama, communities such as Zhizo and Leopard's Kopje began building terrace walls around <htdate0>. Given this context, it is possible that the construction of the walls began between the late 12th and early 13th centuries, according to the Gregorian calendar (<htcite0>)

source.text: Chirikure, S., Pollard, M., Manyanga, M., & Bandama, F.

history.text:
#### Social Organization

The succession of rulers at Great Zimbabwe is generally analyzed based on the later Mutapa State (<htcite0>).

Successions in the Mutapa State did not always occur through a single lineage—sons succeeding their fathers. Similarly, it is possible that at Great Zimbabwe, some kings were also replaced by their brothers, as was the case in the Mutapa State (<htcite1>).

sources.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

history.text:
From Period III onwards, for the first time, we can state something with greater clarity about the men who inhabited the Greater Zimbabwe region. Even if we cannot name them yet, we know their haplogroup is E1b1a* (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>), which is why, in this final section of the text, we chose to focus on a male figure.

One final point we would like to highlight, emphasized in one of the articles used in this text, is the small number of studies related to many regions of Africa (<htcite3>). As a direct consequence, we still have much to discover about the people who have lived for millennia in these regions. On the other hand, due to a lack of data in classrooms or everyday conversations, it is also possible to reach mistaken conclusions about these populations, a fact that leads us to one final reflection.

source.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

history.text:
Reflection 2: On Our Knowledge

Have you ever heard it said that there was nothing before the colonizers arrived in Africa?

If so, upon hearing that phrase, didn't it bother you to think that the cradle of humanity would have nothing?

If there were more studies in Africa, could this scenario of ignorance be transformed?
We can affirm that relationships like this existed, due to present and past generations.
Genetic data presented in the analyzed studies demonstrate their existence through people alive today (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>)

source.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

exercise_v2.question: Não havia ninguém no grande Zimbábue antes da chegada do povo Shona?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: A chegada do povo Shona ocorre após o Período I. Apesar de não haver muitos dados a respeito, não podemos negar a existência de uma população anterior.

exercise_v2.question: O povo Shona foi um povo completamente isolado apenas conhecendo o mundo exterior com a chegara dos europeus?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Evidências arqueológicas demonstram que séculos antes da chegadas dos europeus na região, o povo Shona já praticava importação de objetos da Ásia.
